message_1:
A data matrix contains the following observations for three variables x, y, and z:

$${\begin{bmatrix} 2 & 4 & 6 & 8 & 10 \\ 3 & 6 & 9 & 12 & 15 \\ 4 & 8 & 12 & 16 & 20 \end{bmatrix}}$$

Perform principal component analysis on this data matrix and find the eigenvalues and eigenvectors.
message_2:
To perform principal component analysis (PCA) on the given data matrix, we need to follow these steps:

1. Standardize the data (if necessary)
2. Calculate the covariance matrix
3. Calculate the eigenvalues and eigenvectors of the covariance matrix

Step 1: Standardize the data
In this case, the data is already standardized (each variable is a multiple of the other), so we can skip this step.

Step 2: Calculate the covariance matrix
The covariance matrix for the given data matrix is:

$$C = \frac{1}{n-1} \begin{bmatrix} \sum_{i=1}^n (x_i - \bar{x})^2 & \sum_{i=1}^n (x_i - \bar{x})(y_i - \bar{y}) & \sum_{i=1}^n (x_i - \bar{x})(z_i - \bar{z}) \\ \sum_{i=1}^n (y_i - \bar{y})(x_i - \bar{x}) & \sum_{i=1}^n (y_i - \bar{y})^2 & \sum_{i=1}^n (y_i - \bar{y})(z_i - \bar{z}) \\ \sum_{i=1}^n (z_i - \bar{z})(x_i - \bar{x}) & \sum_{i=1}^n (z_i - \bar{z})(y_i - \bar{y}) & \sum_{i=1}^n (z_i - \bar{z})^2 \end{bmatrix}$$

For the given data matrix, the means of x, y, and z are:

$$\bar{x} = \frac{2+4+6+8+10}{5} = 6$$
$$\bar{y} = \frac{3+6+9+12+15}{5} = 9$$
$$\bar{z} = \frac{4+8+12+16+20}{5} = 12$$

Calculating the covariance matrix:

$$C = \frac{1}{5-1} \begin{bmatrix} 40 & 60 & 80 \\ 60 & 90 & 120 \\ 80 & 120 & 160 \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 10 & 15 & 20 \\ 15 & 22.5 & 30 \\ 20 & 30 & 40 \end{bmatrix}$$

Step 3: Calculate the eigenvalues and eigenvectors of the covariance matrix
We need to solve the following equation for eigenvalues (λ) and eigenvectors (v):

$$Cv = \lambda v$$

The characteristic equation is:

$$|C - \lambda I| = 0$$

$$\begin{vmatrix} 10-\lambda & 15 & 20 \\ 15 & 22.5-\lambda & 30 \\ 20 & 30 & 40-\lambda \end{vmatrix} = 0$$

Solving the characteristic equation, we get the eigenvalues:

$$\lambda_1 = 72.5, \lambda_2 = 0, \lambda_3 = 0$$

Now, we need to find the eigenvectors for each eigenvalue:

For λ1 = 72.5:

$$(C - 72.5I)v_1 = 0$$

$$\begin{bmatrix} -62.5 & 15 & 20 \\ 15 & -50 & 30 \\ 20 & 30 & -32.5 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} v_{11} \\ v_{12} \\ v_{13} \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 0 \\ 0 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix}$$

Solving this system, we get the eigenvector:

$$v_1 = \begin{bmatrix} 2 \\ 3 \\ 4 \end{bmatrix}$$

For λ2 = 0 and λ3 = 0, the eigenvectors are not unique, and any vector orthogonal to v1 can be an eigenvector. We can choose two orthogonal vectors as:

$$v_2 = \begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ -2 \\ 1 \end{bmatrix}, v_3 = \begin{bmatrix} -2 \\ 1 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix}$$

So, the eigenvalues and eigenvectors for the given data matrix are:

Eigenvalues: λ1 = 72.5, λ2 = 0, λ3 = 0
Eigenvectors: v1 = [2, 3, 4], v2 = [1, -2, 1], v3 = [-2, 1, 0]
